title: Best and worst practices with AI

blocks.text: Best practices: Using AI to support writing

AI is not inherently harmful to student writers. Far from it. When student writers use it wisely, it can help them free up valuable time and energy so that they can focus on tasks that benefit from their passion, creativity and humanityâ€”tasks like writing!

As a rule of thumb, uses of AI that preserve the writing process are best. By contrast, you should not use AI to skip the stages of invention, drafting, revision, and so on, nor should you use it to remove your own cognitive contribution from any stage.

items.title: Gather sources
items.body: Use AI to help you gather sources for a writing assignment.

items.title: Suggest topics
items.body: Use AI to suggest potential topics or writing ideas.

items.title: Simulate peer review
items.body: Use AI to simulate peer review-like feedback.

items.title: Spell-check functions
items.body: Use AI to perform spell-check-like functions.

items.title: Generate practice prompts
items.body: Use AI to generate practice prompts.

items.title: Generate decorative elements
items.body: Use AI to generate decorative, non-written elements (e.g., images for presentations).

blocks.text: Worst practices: Using AI to avoid writing

Relying on AI to perform certain intellectual tasks prevents you from becoming more proficient in those tasks. For this reason, using AI to bypass, replace, or otherwise avoid the writing process (in whole or in part) is not a good idea.

items.title: Don't generate drafts
items.body: Don't feed assignment directions into an LLM in order to produce a draft.

items.title: Don't add unread sources
items.body: Don't use AI to add sources you haven't read into your writing.

items.title: Don't do extensive revisions
items.body: Don't use AI to do extensive revisions on an existing work to make it appear new.

items.title: Don't skip review
items.body: Don't use AI for style revisions or spell-check functions without reviewing changes.

blocks.text: Keep in mind that many of the 'worst practice' examples would very likely be considered violations of your institution's academic integrity policies.
